fields.description:
When configuring [Amazon S3 artifact storage|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOOCLOUD/Amazon+S3+artifact+storage] the dialog shows a checkmark after saving the configuration with the Amazon S3 bucket but there might be problems if the bucket doesn't have the correct policies to grant Bamboo access.

*Steps to reproduce:*
Link a S3 bucket name in Bamboo "Artifact Storage" section.

*Error:*
{noformat}
Forbidden (Service: Amazon S3; Status Code: 403; Error Code: 403 Forbidden; Request ID: A589XXXXXXXXEB)
{noformat}

It would be good to have a check done when the bucket is linked or a popup with information on how to configure the policies to avoid errors.

*To Solve de error:*
* Create a policy by following [Amazon Policy guide|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/example-bucket-policies.html] and [AWS Policy Generator|http://awspolicygen.s3.amazonaws.com/policygen.html] to grant permissions to Bamboo on the S3 Bucket.
{code}{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Sid": "Stmt1434671502112",
      "Action": [
        "s3:DeleteObject",
        "s3:DeleteObjectVersion",
        "s3:GetBucketLocation",
        "s3:GetObject",
        "s3:GetObjectAcl",
        "s3:GetObjectVersion",
        "s3:GetObjectVersionAcl",
        "s3:ListBucket",
        "s3:PutObject",
        "s3:PutObjectAcl",
        "s3:PutObjectVersionAcl"
      ],
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::atlassian-net-bamboo-artifacts"
    }
  ]
}{code}
More user configurations [here|http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6615168/s3-policy-limiting-access-to-only-one-bucket-listing-included]
fields.summary: S3 Storage configuration doesn't check or warn permissions on the S3 Bucket

fields.description:
When:
- an elastic image configuration has an invalid (e.g. non-existent) subnet configured, and
- there is a build queued that requires this image configuration

then Bamboo refuses to spin up *any* image configuration to handle any queued builds.

In our case we changed all our VPC subnets and forgot to update one of the image configurations with the new values.

The server logs reveal the following:
{noformat}
2015-06-18 01:36:17,588 INFO [scheduler_Worker-10] [ElasticRunningInstancesOptimizerImpl] 5 elastic instance(s) will be started for those builds that cannot be build on currently connected agents.
2015-06-18 01:36:17,588 INFO [scheduler_Worker-10] [ElasticRunningInstancesOptimizerImpl] 5 elastic instance(s) will be started to run builds that are waiting in a queue. Current queue size is 198, number of builds executable on elastic agents is 183. Bamboo is currently starting 14 elastic instances.
2015-06-18 01:36:17,588 INFO [scheduler_Worker-10] [ElasticRunningInstancesOptimizerImpl] AWS account has 588 elastic instances started by Bamboo server(s) and has 0 spot requests pending, 588 in total. Of these, Bamboo controls 67.
2015-06-18 01:36:17,691 INFO [scheduler_Worker-10] [SubnetCache] query for a non-existing resource [subnet-64fd5a13]
2015-06-18 01:36:17,691 ERROR [scheduler_Worker-10] [ElasticInstancesMonitorJob] Failed to adjust the number of elastic agents.
com.atlassian.aws.AWSException: Error when starting a new instance
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.elastic.server.ElasticFunctionalityFacadeImpl.startupAgents(ElasticFunctionalityFacadeImpl.java:218)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.elastic.schedule.ElasticInstancesMonitorJob.execute(ElasticInstancesMonitorJob.java:50)
    at org.quartz.core.JobRunShell.run(JobRunShell.java:202)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.utils.BambooRunnables$1.run(BambooRunnables.java:49)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper.runWith(ImpersonationHelper.java:31)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper.runWithSystemAuthority(ImpersonationHelper.java:20)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper$1.run(ImpersonationHelper.java:52)
    at org.quartz.simpl.SimpleThreadPool$WorkerThread.run(SimpleThreadPool.java:525)
Caused by: com.atlassian.aws.ec2.caches.Ec2CacheMissException: The resource with ID 'subnet-64fd5a13' does not exist (Service: AmazonEC2; Status Code: 400; Error Code: InvalidSubnetID.NotFound; Request ID: none)
    at com.atlassian.aws.ec2.caches.SubnetCache.onResourceLookupFailure(SubnetCache.java:48)
    at com.atlassian.aws.AwsOmeCache.filterResources(AwsOmeCache.java:90)
    at com.atlassian.aws.AwsOmeCache.filterResources(AwsOmeCache.java:85)
    at com.atlassian.aws.AwsOmeCache.describe(AwsOmeCache.java:114)
    at com.atlassian.aws.AwsOmeCache.describeResources(AwsOmeCache.java:127)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.elastic.server.ElasticFunctionalityFacadeImpl.getVpcsAndSubnets(ElasticFunctionalityFacadeImpl.java:278)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.elastic.server.ElasticFunctionalityFacadeImpl.ensureSecurityGroupsExist(ElasticFunctionalityFacadeImpl.java:290)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.agent.elastic.server.ElasticFunctionalityFacadeImpl.startupAgents(ElasticFunctionalityFacadeImpl.java:179)
    ... 7 more
{noformat}

Valid image configurations could still be started manually and would pick up builds during this time. Correcting the image configuration to use valid subnets immediately fixed the problem.

The impact to us was that our unwitting back-end mistake caused many of our Bamboo servers to lose most of their build capacity, and it was not obvious what the problem was.

I would have expected:
- Bamboo to continue being able to spin up instances from other image configurations to handle the builds that didn't require this one particular (invalid) image config; and
- a visible error in the UI reporting that there was a problem when trying to launch that image configuration.
fields.summary: One bad image configuration can block all automatic elastic instance management

fields.description:
Our current build plans in bamboo generate some git commits as part of a shared repository (several .Jar Files and some documentation) . 

I've not tested this, but using "Stash Repository Trigger" since this repository is shared across plans and I assume Plan A will cause Plan B to build, which will trigger Plan A and cause an endless loop of builds. 

I propose that the "Stash Repository Trigger" needs an option to select which repositories to poll the same way that the "Poll Repository" trigger does.
fields.summary: Ability to chose which Repositories will Trigger build using "Stash repository trigger"

fields.description:
Hello,

This may be related to STASH-7508 as I'm having problems after rebooting my server which runs both Stash and Bamboo (and JIRA, Fisheye, Confluence) - Windows Server 2012 R2 / MS SQL 2014 Standard.  The icons that show a build in progress on the main dashboard just keep animating.  I go to linked repositories and click each (about a dozen) and save again to see if that helps.  As outlined in the Stash case I can't push a Git commit without restarting that service so it may be a Stash issue. But either way, I cannot trust rebooting my Windows Server with Stash and Bamboo services not appearing to start properly and have valid communications.  I have to restart each of the two services after the reboot to get things going again, Stash first of course.

Bamboo 5.9.0 which is not available in the list below for affected versions.
fields.summary: After server reboot Bamboo has issues connecting to Stash

fields.summary: Reordering of Builds fails for Deployments

fields.description:
Please add a Filter to the Deployment Projects List
/deploy/viewAllDeploymentProjects.action

Our organization has a growing number of deployment projects, I would like to see just the ones that I work on.
fields.summary: Deployment Projects Filter

fields.description:
It would be great to have a report that could list all software packages deployed to all units, grouped by the software name and version
The result could be grouped by Domain > Name, Deployment > SW Package Name[Deployed] and Deployment > SW Package Version[Deployed], and the rows could be sorted by Unit Name.
fields.summary: Deployment Report in Bamboo

fields.description: This is currently not possible, and it would be great to have this feature added to Bamboo.
fields.summary: Allow Bamboo plan to trigger on P4 shelved code

fields.description:
On Bamboo Cloud it's not possible to delete a repository cache that has a branch which is named using special character.

*Steps to reproduce:*
Create a branch on a repository and name it using a special character (let's say _tést_)
Configure a plan to use this branch
Fire a build so it's cached
Go to _Repository settings_ and try to delete all caches
The following error is presented:
{panel:bgColor=red}Deleting of Git cache 'ac181b993ea7b72496db4b7fbe3318eb68cc1c24' failed: File does not exist: /data/jirastudio/bamboo/home/xml-data/build-dir/_git-repositories-cache/ac181b993ea7b72496db4b7fbe3318eb68cc1c24/.git/refs/heads/t��st{panel}
fields.summary: Unable to delete repository cache if it has a branch named using special characters

fields.description: Configured Bamboo to run our own jar file and its failing in between because of file open dialog
fields.summary: Configured Bamboo to run our own jar file and its failing in between because of file open dialog

fields.description: Create a plan. Add a manual stage. Commit to repository it points to. Notice that the optional stage is not run. Go to build history. Read the incorrect statement "Bamboo builds everything whenever the repository changes."
fields.summary: Bamboo incorrectly claims it builds everything whenever the repository changes.

fields.description:
e.g. a commit to the external references by a folder within a directory project/source/libraries/externalLibraryHere will not trigger a build. However if the external is at the level projectexternalLibraryHere it would work. 

Please fix this so that commits to externals in subdirectories trigger builds. Without this working development on libraries do not trigger builds. For some projects most of the development is in libraries. It is essential that commits to externals in sub directories trigger builds. It is not feasible to change the directory layout to work around this just for bamboo.

Note: this was observed with subversion.
fields.summary: Build does not trigger on changes to externals in subdirectories

fields.description: At the moment the main integration between using Chef and puppet is via script tasks. Some larger customers who use this heavily may benefit from a tighter integration with Chef with a dedicated Chef task and better interaction.
fields.summary: Bamboo and Puppet integration

fields.description:
Whenever i run a manual build i want it to run NOW.
There should be a possibility to skip checking for repo's i dont want to build now anyway.

We are waiting for 5-10 minutes for every manual build. It would be nice to have a button to stop checking for other sources.

Thank you for looking into this!
fields.summary: Skip the queue button

fields.description:
Bamboo will currently run a child plan whenever the parent plan completes, regardless if the child has a branch plan configured for the branch the parent just finished.

In order to support having a "master" plan that then has many children that do different things depending on the branch name, Bamboo should have an option to respect the child plan branches.

This has come up because we have multiple platforms to QA on, but only need to run those QA jobs on some subset of parent plan builds which can be identified by the branch name. E.g. that branches containing the string "project1" in their name should trigger child1 after building, and branches containing the string "project2" should trigger child2.
fields.summary: Child plan should not run if it does not have a branch plan that matches the parent

fields.description:
*Background*
Scheduled Backups makes Bamboo "Paused". So the Scheduled Build does not run while Scheduled Backups is running.
Moving the Scheduled Build backward is not good workaround. Because the Scheduled Backups will need more time, sooner or later.

There is not the option to make the Scheduled Build running after completing the Scheduled Backups.

*Request*
Add the option to make the Scheduled Build running after completing the Scheduled Backups.
fields.summary: The option to make the Scheduled Build running after completing the Scheduled Backups.

fields.description:
SSH server "OpenSSH_6.7p1 Debian-5, OpenSSL 1.0.1k 8 Jan 2015" is not compatible with SSHJ 0.10.0 which bamboo-scp-plugin uses now, so some clients may have problems with SSH and SCP tasks when try to get to server.

Issue is solved at SSHJ 0.12.0: https://github.com/hierynomus/sshj

Workaround: use Script task to upload files to this server
fields.summary: Upgrade bamboo-scp-plugin to use SSHJ 0.12.0

fields.description:
We have a project that imports BOMs from jboss (Kie, jbpm...) one of these boms has the artifact org.jboss:jboss-parent:11:jar as its parent. 
This POM has the following lines:

{noformat}
  <dependencyManagement>
    <dependencies>
      <dependency>
        <groupId>com.sun</groupId>
        <artifactId>tools</artifactId>
        <scope>system</scope>
        <version>1.6</version>
        <systemPath>${com.sun.tools.path}</systemPath>
      </dependency>
    </dependencies>
  </dependencyManagement>
{noformat}

The property com.sun.tools.path is defined in the same POM as ${java.home}/../lib/tools.jar.
When the Maven Dependency Processor Task is executed, it fails with the following message:

{noformat}
 error	10-Jun-2015 11:49:38	Automatic Maven plan dependencies processing failed: org.apache.maven.project.ProjectBuildingException: Some problems were encountered while processing the POMs:
 [ERROR] 'dependencyManagement.dependencies.dependency.systemPath' for com.sun:tools:jar must specify an absolute path but is ${java.home}/../lib/tools.jar @ org.jboss:jboss-parent:11, D:\maven_repository\.m2\repository\org\jboss\jboss-parent\11\jboss-parent-11.pom, line 171, column 21
 [ERROR] 'dependencyManagement.dependencies.dependency.systemPath' for com.sun:tools:jar must specify an absolute path but is ${java.home}/../lib/tools.jar @ org.jboss:jboss-parent:11, D:\maven_repository\.m2\repository\org\jboss\jboss-parent\11\jboss-parent-11.pom, line 171, column 21
{noformat}

I tried to override the value for com.sun.tools.path in the settings, but that doesn't seem to have any effect, not even in Maven (checked with help:effective-pom).

I added a dependency management for the sun.com:tools before importing the boms, that results in a correct effective pom. but the dependency processor still fails with the same message
fields.summary: Maven Dependency Processor does not resolve ${java.home}

fields.description:
The Deployment project summary page (/deploy/viewDeploymentProjectEnvironments.action?id=X) shows a list of all the environments for the project and the release that each environment is on. It also includes the time/date when the deployment for each environment occurred.

This time/date there is shown using the timezone detected in the user's browser rather than the configured timezone of the server.

Clicking into that environment will show the time in the expected server-configured timezone.

I have attached screenshots illustrating the problematic behaviour (environment overview -- showing *10 Jun 2015 11:08 AM*) and the correct behaviour (environment detail view -- showing *10 Jun 2015 01:08 AM*) of the same deployment where the browser is in GMT+10 and the server is in GMT+0.
fields.summary: Deployment project summary displays times in wrong timezone

fields.description:
In Bamboo 5.8.0 and 5.8.1 the Windows Stock Image (Windows Server 2012 R2) AMI contain a 'bamboo' user which is configured with a publicly known password. While the 'bamboo' user is not allowed RDP access it was permitted to login through SSH on instances using the affected AMI. In the event that a vulnerable live agent is discovered by an attacker, the attacker could use this vulnerability to SSH into an affected Elastic Agents as the 'bamboo' user and execute arbitrary commands as that user. As builds execute as the 'bamboo' user an attacker would have access to any files used or generated as part of builds.

*Bamboo Server builds may have been affected if all of the following conditions are true:*
# Bamboo was running version 5.8.0 or 5.8.1 after the ﻿17 Mar 2015 and before 01 Apr 2015.
# A build was configured to use a Windows Stock Image (Windows Server 2012 R2) AMI with an accessible port 22. That port is not accessible at all if 'elasticbamboo' Security Group has been modified to exclude port 22. The port is not accessible from the public Internet if the instances were running in a VPC with public addressing disabled.
# The build was run before  01 Apr 2015. (After the 01 Apr 2015 the bamboo user password expired which prevents the bamboo user from logging in.)

Bamboo Server 5.9.0 is available with the fixed AMI and is available for download from https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download.

For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/eQfoL].
fields.summary: CVE-2015-4136: SSH Authorisation permitted for a user with hard-coded credentials in Windows Stock Image (Windows Server 2012 R2) AMI

Constraint in question: is foreign key on PLAN_VCS_HISTORY

fields.description:
Here I'm assuming (as suggested in the Bamboo room) that dependent build should check out the same repository at the same revision as the parent build.

Parent https://engservices-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/browse/MICROS-SERVER-14 Dependent build https://engservices-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/browse/MICROS-SERVERRELEASE-4 

It shows me that the revision is the same but as you may notice there is one more commit in the dependent build. That commit happened few days ago but was merged into master while the parent plan was being built and before the dependent was triggered. I don't know if dependent build actually checked out correct or wrong revision (someone may want to doublecheck this), but the commit list is clearly not correct.

/cc [~ccalvo]

fields.description:
In the bamboo linux installation manual there is a hidden box about java installation - [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Installing+Bamboo+on+Linux#expander-control-2119564004]

In it is the following instruction:
'echo JAVA_HOME="path/to/JAVA_HOME" >> /etc/environment'

I took it a bit forward, and made my /etc/environment look like this:

JAVA_HOME=/usr/java/default
PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH

(as one would usually do in /etc/profile)

This (adding the PATH configuration here) caused me to break my shell in CentOS 7. To fix it I had to load the installation media and delete the contents of /etc/environment in recovery mode.

Perhaps you can add a warning about it so other people won't do this mistake.
fields.summary: Tricky instructions

fields.description: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/17567/wrong-maven2-environment-variables
fields.summary: Wrong Maven2 environment variables

fields.description:
Currently, dedicating an agent to a plan creates a reciprocal dedication of the plan to that agent.

Dedicating an agent to a plan *shouldn't* limit that plan to that agent. 

Dedicating an agent to plan allows you to reserve an agent so that plans always have some agents available.  But if the dedicated agent is busy, and a non-dedicated agent is free, it should run any queued jobs.
fields.summary: Don't limit plan to an agent

fields.description:
On Step 2 of [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO057/Securing%20your%20remote%20agents], the following code should not have spaces surrounding the = sign following SSL_OPTS.  This fails in Ubuntu Server 12.04's bash.  Additionally, we found we needed to surround the parameters with quotes so bash didn't try to parse the data--particularly the password.



export SSL_OPTS = -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStore=/path/to/server.ks -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword=password
fields.summary: Documentation bug: spaces around = in bash command

fields.summary: Configure LDAP through Web UI

fields.description:
h2. Problem
When accessing *Plan Configuration > Branches*, there is an option for *Plan branch cleanup*, specifying the number of days a plan branch can be inactive (no commits made), before it is removed.

The default setting is {{30}} days, however entering any new value will not be stored, the form is submitted but the value then remains 30 days.

!branchconfig.png|thumbnail!

h2. Resolution
This bug was fixed during an UI rework in Bamboo 5.9.x, so the resolution is to upgrade to 5.9.x+.

h2. Workaround.
This setting is stored in the {{build_definiton}} table in the {{XML_DEFINITION_DATA}} column. You will need to locate the following and update the value accordingly:
{code:xml}    <inactivityInDays>30</inactivityInDays>{code}

To find the corresponding {{BUILD_ID}}, refer to the database table {{build}}.

For these settings to be picked up by Bamboo, you will need to restart the instance.

(!) Make sure to create a database backup before issuing any modification.
fields.summary: "Remove after" value is not saved on plan configuration screen

fields.description: Bamboo has the ability to cron tasks, but under heavy load may delay the pickup of the task along with the natural delay when an agent waits to poll for work. An improvement for Bamboo would be to have a dedicated agent accept a cron'ed job that would simply deploy directly to the agent, skipping the queue.
fields.summary: Cron tasks should bypass the queue to guarantee scheduling

fields.description:
In version 5.8.1 the deployment projects do not have any features that will allow a manual Stage/Task/Job to be run during the deployment project.

A good example is when bringing up a website to be a manual Stage/Task/Job.
As your website may have to wait for many other external processes to be finished before your website can be brought back online.  
The manual Stage/Task/Job would be most suitable.
fields.summary: Add Manual Stage/Tasks/Jobs to deployment projects

fields.description:
Using the Mocha test reporter, when I have 5 tests that take 400 ms each, the total time is being reported as <1 second. It should be 2 seconds.

I think what's happening is the individual test times are being converted to seconds before being added together. The conversion should be happening after; i.e. the total sum should be done in milliseconds and then converted to seconds, rather than the individual test times being converted to seconds and then summed.
fields.summary: Total test duration is incorrect

With freeSSHD installed on Windows, ssh clients such as PuTTY and UNIX terminal can SSH into Windows and execute batch commands.

However, when using a SSH task, the following error is thrown:
{noformat}Unable to execute command or shell on remote system: Failed to Execute process.{noformat}

The command that was tried is {{dir}}.

From my testing, only {{ls}} (with cygwin installed on the server) works. All other commands like echo and dir fails.
fields.summary: SSH Task with Windows freeSSHD

fields.description:
In version 5.8.1 there is not way to expire artifacts immediately after a build.

For example. 

My first stage job in the build is to check out the source code and turn that into an artifact.
Then the artifact is shared to the next stages and jobs.

I would like the option to expire the source code artifact once the entire build is completed.
fields.summary: Expire artifact once build is complete.

fields.description:
In version 5.8.1 there is the option to check the 

'Clean working directory after each build' in Miscellaneous on a build job.  

The assumption is that checking this value will clear out the entire job folder's content after the entire build has completed as the name says so. 

To my unfortunate surprise the clean actually occurs before the entire project build is actually complete and the way that the project is set up in my instance the entire build fails.

I would like to propose a simple check in the plan configuration 
'Clean all working directories after entire build' which would make more sense for the name and would function as a single clean for all of the job folders after the entire build has been completed (whether successful or not).
fields.summary: Add an option to clean directory before a build happens
The API key field on the HipChat notification configuration does not trim whitespace

fields.description:
Currently, clients are required to spend some time reading through documentation [Securing Bamboo with Tomcat using SSL|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Securing+Bamboo+with+Tomcat+using+SSL] in order to run Bamboo behind Tomcat SSL. Since we provide a connector that listen on port 8085 by default, it would be interesting on providing a new connector (i.e.: 8443) where Bamboo could be listed on HTTPS protocol.
{code:xml}
<Connector port="8443" maxHttpHeaderSize="8192" SSLEnabled="true"
	maxThreads="150" minSpareThreads="25"
	enableLookups="false" disableUploadTimeout="true"
	acceptCount="100" scheme="https" secure="true"
	clientAuth="false" sslProtocol="TLS" useBodyEncodingForURI="true"
	keystoreFile="PATH_TO_KEYSTORE"
	keystorePass="PASSWORD"
	keyAlias="ALIAS"/>
{code}
Along with that, a set of "{{KEYSTORE}}" and "{{SSLCertificate}} that could be used by the application in order to run it under the protocol HTTPS out-of-box.
* keystoreFile
* keystorePass
* keyAlias
* SSLCertificateFile
* SSLCertificateKeyFile
fields.summary: Pre-configured Tomcat SSL embedded in release

fields.description: The first time a branch plan runs, it does not estimate how long it is going to take, and so does not show progress bars for the individual jobs or for the plan either on the page or in the title bar.  It would be nice if the first time a branch build ran it grabbed its estimates from the last time the master branch ran so that it has something to work from.
fields.summary: Obtain build progress estimates from base plan for first-time branch builds

fields.description:
*User impact*
 can't generate report for plan with manual stage which was not started

*Description*
If plan has manual stage then buildDate field of AbstractResultSummary for this build is null until user manually run this particular stage. 
This field is used on report generator to sort data on report preparation phase. If this field is null for some records it can put record into incorrect place of collection. Then we iterate on collection expecting that first element is the earliest event in series. If at the middle of collection we found element with getStatDate() earlier than current RegularTimePeriod we can't find next corresponding RegularTimePeriod and go over 9999 years limit of JFreeChart.

Also nullability of this field doesn't allow user to filter records by date on Reports UI

The following appear in the log files:
{noformat}
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Null 'key' argument.
	at org.jfree.data.DefaultKeyedValues2D.getRowIndex(DefaultKeyedValues2D.java:184)
	at org.jfree.data.DefaultKeyedValues2D.setValue(DefaultKeyedValues2D.java:321)
	at org.jfree.data.DefaultKeyedValues2D.addValue(DefaultKeyedValues2D.java:304)

Affected region:

Non-affected:

The list is still not completed.

fields.description: When Bamboo is behind a reverse proxy, Bamboo should check the remote agent request of {{X-Real-IP or X-Forwarded-For}} headers to determine the real ip address of the remote agents.

fields.description:
We locked down the System info and log setting pages on Bamboo Cloud for security reasons. See https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-15736 for more information.

It would be great to be able to provide a trimmed version of the System information page with at least version number and uptime so that customer can see basic information about their instance.
fields.summary: Make Bamboo version and uptime available to Cloud customers

fields.description:
It would be nice to have the ability to meticulously look and compare the changes made to a Plan and even opt to revert them back. Currently the audit logs display the information in a simple and straightforward method, but it doesn't highlight what exactly was changed nor give us options to act upon the information. Here's an improvement sample:

!audit-log.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Advanced way to compare changes in Plan audit logs

fields.description: When debugging has been enabled for notifications also include the return codes from HipChat connection attempts (404, 500, 200 etc) in the debug logs.
fields.summary: Better HipChat API debug logging

fields.description:
h2.Summary

It is not possible to delete *Shared Credentials* from Bamboo with an Administrator privilege. 

{code}
2015-05-29 15:49:32.722163500 2015-05-29 15:49:32,721 WARN [TP-Processor37] [AuthorizationLoggerListener] Authorization failed: org.acegisecurity.AuthorizationServiceException: A Collection or an array (or null) was required as the returnedObject, but the returnedObject was: []; authenticated principal: org.acegisecurity.adapters.PrincipalAcegiUserToken@1c28fae6: Username: vchin; Password: [PROTECTED]; Authenticated: true; Details: null; Granted Authorities: ROLE_USER, ROLE_RESTRICTEDADMIN; secure object: ReflectiveMethodInvocation: public abstract java.lang.Iterable com.atlassian.bamboo.deployments.environments.service.EnvironmentService.getAllEnvironments(); target is of class [com.atlassian.bamboo.deployments.environments.service.EnvironmentServiceImpl]; configuration attributes: [ROLE_USER, ROLE_ANONYMOUS, AFTER_ACL_COLLECTION_READ]
{code}

From the error above; it seems that the administrator requires sysadmin access in order to remove the *Shared Credentials*. From the documentation; you don't need to have sysadmin access to remove it.

!Untitled.png|thumbnail!

h2.Steps to Replicate

Attempt to remove a *Shared Credential* with an administrator account.

h2.Workaround

No workaround available for now besides requesting assistance of support to remove the *Shared Credentials*
fields.summary: Cannot delete Shared Credentials

fields.description:
I have a subversion project that uses an external, and the external project has externals of its own.  However, the Bamboo server looks only one level deep when checking for modifications in my build, and  consequently, updates to our common code don't trigger rebuilds.

I'm able to work around this issue but it would be nice to have this work automatically, so I can configure my project in subversion without having to worry about maintaining a parallel configuration on the build server.
fields.summary: Would like "Detect changes in externals" to be applied recursively

fields.description:
It would be nice to have a search mechanism in Bamboo to both Plan and System audit logs. This way users can easily try to find what they're looking for instead of having to go over all the information and pages. Specially because audit logs inside Plans are very meticulous, meaning that a lot of information is stored there and you can easily find yourself lost trying to filter/find a specific information. As an example, JIRA has a similar search mechanism in its audit log interface:

!search-mechanism.png!
fields.summary: Provide search mechanism to both Plan and System audit logs

fields.description:
When a user manually starts a build, s/he should have the option to select on which Agent it should run.
This is useful when there are multiple Agents, but the user wants it to build on the fastest one.
fields.summary: As a user I would like to select the Remote Agent when starting a manual build

fields.description:
Assume you have multiple Agents, all with the same capabilities.
Some of the Agents run on fast hardware, some on slow hardware.
The slow Agents are there to avoid builds from getting queued if there are multiple builds at the same time.

Obviously you want a build to run on the fastest Agent available.
However, currently the Bamboo server will pick a random Agent for a build.

It would be useful if you can specify an Agent priority.
The fastest available Agent would then be picked first, and the slowest Agent last.
fields.summary: Prioritize Agents based on speed

fields.description:
The REST API documentation (https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/REST) could use come revision and improvements to be more in like with existing Atlasssian Documentation.   

For example the landing page has limited explanation as to what is being presented and some of the REST examples the "expand" field will not contain any information.
fields.summary: Improve the Bamboo REST API documentation
Broken documentation link in error message about unsupported upgrade from pre-4.0 version

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When the customer attempts to create a new instance schedule, the image config dropdown lists all of the available images multiple times. This makes it extremely difficult to pick the correct image.

h3. Environment
Bamboo Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Log into Bamboo Cloud in the customers instance 
Click on 'Instance Schedules' link in the left hand menu
Click on the 'Image config' dropdown

h3. Expected Results

One listing per image type available should be displayed

h3. Actual Results
Multiple listings for what appear to be the same image are displayed 

***Screenshot attached

h3.Workaround
No current work around known for this
fields.summary: Image config dropdown duplicates image names

fields.description:
h4. Steps to reproduce:
- Generate an artifact that is one directory containing a second directory containing some test file and an {{index.html}} file
- Define this artifact in Bamboo
- Run the build
- Attempt to access the parent directory of index.html via the browser
-- Example: {{<INSERT BAMBOO BASE URL HERE>/artifact/FOO-II/shared/build-2/test/dir1/dir2}} where dir2 contains index.html and a couple other files.

h4. Expected result
The directory is returned to the browser displaying all contents

h4. Actual result
The browser is automatically directed to index.html

h4. Workaround:
The artifacts can still be accessed directly with the fully qualified address to the specific part of the package.
fields.summary: Bamboo not respecting HTTP artifact paths

fields.description:
[Dragons Stage 8 - Install Bamboo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/ATLAS/Dragons+Stage+8+-+Install+Bamboo] provides an example on how to link repositories, as per:

[Step 6. Set up a Project and Run a Build|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/ATLAS/Dragons+Stage+8+-+Install+Bamboo#DragonsStage8-InstallBamboo-Step6.SetupaProjectandRunaBuild]

However, in order to clone from the repository, it is required to have [Mercurial|https://mercurial.selenic.com/] installed and added as a [Bamboo Capability|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Defining+a+new+version+control+capability]
!bamboo.mercurialCapability.png|thumbnail!

If you visit https://bitbucket.org/atlassian_dragons/dragonslayers you will notice the repository does not use Git but Mercurial (hg) instead:
{noformat}
# [USERNAME], i.e.: atlassian_dragons
hg clone https://[USERNAME]@bitbucket.org/atlassian_dragons/dragonslayers
{noformat}
fields.summary: Documentation - Dragons Stage 8, required Mercurial to clone from Bitbucket repository

fields.description:
When a branch is removed in Git, Bamboo detects it and disables the branch plan. When the branch with the same name is created, Bamboo creates a new branch plan rather than reusing the existing disabled one.

Bamboo should check the branch name with existing branch plan names if one exist already.

Documentation Update Request: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+upgrade+guide

{quote}
h4. Stop Bamboo
Stop Bamboo as usual.

If you have Bamboo running as a Windows service, you should uninstall this service, using the UninstallService.bat executable that came with your existing Bamboo instance.
{quote}

We should point customers who are uninstalling the Windows service to https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Running+Bamboo+as+a+Windows+service+as+the+local+user if they use a local user account. Some admins may not be the original admin and might be unaware that re-configuring the user account is necessary once reinstalling the Bamboo service as the default account may not have the proper permissions to preform key features of Bamboo.

fields.description:
We have been using Bamboo for about a year.  For about 6+ months it would occasionally get CPU bound and get slower and slower to respond before eventually failing to respond altogether.

Of late this has become MUCH more frequent.  Now 2-3 times a week.  Also, I don't know if it is related, but most Mondays we arrive to find it has crashed altogether.

I split the catalina.out file on today's date to reduce its size significantly and have attached that.

Let me know if you need any other information.
fields.summary: Bamboo regularly becomes CPU bound and grinds to a halt

fields.description:
I have installed a bamboo remote agent to our Bamboo server instance (5.8.1 build 5866) on a Mac Mini running 10.10.3 with build version 14D136. 

On the machine I get the following: 

dev-1:  sudo /Applications/Bamboo/bin/bamboo-agent.sh status
Bamboo Agent is running (10524).

On the server I get: 

May 25, 2015 11:28:18 AM A remote agent is loading on 192.168.56.1 (0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1).
May 25, 2015 11:28:26 AM Remote agent [172.21.1.56] marked as inactive. A new one came in place.
May 25, 2015 11:28:26 AM Remote agent [172.21.1.56] came back after a period of inactivity.
May 25, 2015 12:21:23 PM Remote agent 'Mobile Dev Remote Agent 1' was unresponsive and has gone offline.

Why is the server thinking the remote agent is offline? This happens several times a day. What can I do to ensure that it does not occur all the time? It doesn't really work as expected if I manually has to restart the server every time this happens.
fields.summary: Bamboo remote agent on Mac OS 10.10.3 is considered to be offline even though it's running

fields.description:
h3. Problem
When dedicating an elastic image and the Elastic Bamboo Configuration is disabled or the region is updated the dedication remains even though the image is no longer available to Bamboo.

h3. Expected Behavior
Bamboo should automatically undedicated the agent advising the user what images associated with this configuration are currently dedicated.

h3. Duplication Steps
# Configure Elastic Bamboo
# Dedicate a agent to a build
# Update Elastic Bamboo Step:
** Change the region 
(i) The build will show no agents are available
** Disable EC2

fields.description:
*Repro Steps*
 1. Create a build job for a build plan.
 2. Add a local agent.
 3. Dedicate the agent to perform the build job.
 4. Delete the agent.

*Expected outcome*
 The build job will revert back to using any agent to run the task provided it's requirements are met.

*Actual outcome*
 The build job says "No agents meet this job's requirements."

*Work around*
 I can either:
 * Clone the job and delete the old one.
 * Shutdown Bamboo, *backup the Bamboo database* and use the below SQL to remove orphaned assignments:
{code}delete from agent_assignment where executor_id not in (select queue_id from queue) and executor_type='AGENT';{code}
fields.summary: "No agents meet this job's requirements." after deleting dedicated agent

fields.description:
* Build project setup:
** I have two different git repositories that I check out to create my build, one is the main project (default repository), the other is like dependencies but not compiled as this is PHP and as such not available as libraries that I could build separately.
** To cater for that I use two repositories in the plan, both are defined on the master branch as default.
** The first task of the build job is to checkout the code, the default first (my main project) then the additional repository in a sub directory of the checked out main project.
** The rest of the build is straight forward, just zip the code, tag it and upload it to nexus.
* The Happy Path:
** If I want to build master on both repository it's all good master is checked out on both repositories, it's all good
** If I want to build a specific branch on the main repository and the master on the secondary ** repository, it's all good as well
* The Unhappy Path:
** If I want to build a specific branch on the main repository and a specific branch (either matching the main one or not) on the secondary repository that's when things start to go wrong. I tried a number of configurations:
*** Specify the bamboo.planRepository.2.branchName variable in the branch settings but it seems to be set after the code is checked out.
*** Specify the bamboo.planRepository.2.branch variable in the branch settings but it seems to be set after the code is checked out.
*** Specify the bamboo.planRepository.2.branch.name variable in the branch settings but it seems to be set after the code is checked out.

None of that worked, although the variable are set the specified value it seems to happen after the checkout task rendering the setting of the variables kind of useless.

Thanks for your feedback.
fields.summary: Specify secondary repository at build plan branch level instead of build plan level

fields.description:
Allow to shutdown instances instead of terminating them.

This feature will be valuable for two of the below use cases
1) No need to install the software's each and every time when the instance boot. I understand there is custom image option but it is not useful for some of the cases.
2) Retaining third party libraries locally for multiple builds. e.g. maven local repo.

This feature is on the similar lines like what is currently supported in Jenkins and Hudson for Amazon Ec2 and Azure cloud.
fields.summary: Enable shutdown option for elastic images

fields.description:
h2. Problem:
When using a local or domain account that has full admin permissions to launch a remote agent, Bamboo does not respect the admin account permissions to the system variables. When running a build when a user %PATH% variable is defined, Bamboo assumes user %PATH% variable will be used. 

h2. Duplication Steps:
# Set up a build that requires Powershell
# [Install remote agent|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+remote+agent+installation+guide]
# [Setup remote agent to start as a Windows service using local user|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Running+Bamboo+as+a+Windows+service+as+the+local+user]
# Add user %PATH% variables for the user 
(i) Powershell should be defined as system variable which this user account has access to
# Add Powershell capability to remote agent
# Add Powershell task
# Run build
(i) Once the build fails it should display an error like below:
{noformat}
'powershell' is not recognized as an internal or external command
{noformat}

h2. Expected Behavior:
User %PATH% will be taken in and tacked onto the front of System %PATH% as seen in CMD shell

h2. Workaround:
Remove the user %PATH% defined in Environment Variables

# Right-click Computer/This PC > properties
# Click *Advanced System Settings*
# Click *Environment Variables*
# In User Variables:
## select PATH variable
## click,  Delete
# Restart remote agent service
fields.summary: Bamboo does not respect Windows user with admin permissions if user %PATH% variable set

fields.description:
Hello,

Been using Stash and Bamboo for about a month now and really like it but they both have a similar problem, showing inherited permissions in lower levels.  For example, in Stash you can set project permission and then further down on a repository its own permissions.  It would be nice if when viewing a repo that you could see what permissions are already in affect inherited from the project level.  In bamboo the same applies, you have global permissions and then build/plan permissions but you can't see (or remember) what the higher level permissions are.
Please consider some type of "ghosting" or presentation of existing permissions so they are not duplicated or messed up at a lower level.  In Bamboo I'm also seeing where I have anonymous off globally but when I create a new plan anonymous seems to get checked - probably a bug.

Thank you.
fields.summary: Show inherited permissions from Global to Plan/Build

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently the Docker task only supports the low-level 'docker' command. But for development and testing the recommended method is to use Docker Compose (formerly Fig). 

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be nice to have first-class support for this in Bamboo. In particular adding Docker Compose support to the existing Docker Task, and a Compose capability to the supplied images would save a lot of work when setting up Compose tasks.
 
h3. Workaround 
* Script or Command Task to utilize docker-compose is currently the only option.
fields.summary: Add Fig/Compose support to Docker task

fields.description:
The commandline invoked by the docker run task adds a /data volume to the container, then `cd`s to it with `--workdir`. However this will overrride any `WORKDIR` directive in the Dockerfile, possibly breaking the container execution.

An example Dockerfile that this would break is this one, which runs a Clojure project's tests:

{noformat}
# Fetch 'lein' build tool
RUN curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/technomancy/leiningen/stable/bin/lein -o /usr/local/bin/lein && \
    chmod a+rx /usr/local/bin/lein

# Do not run as root. Ever.
RUN adduser --disabled-password --gecos '' transfer

# We can't mount volumes as non-root, so copy our code in.
ADD . /code
RUN chown -R transfer.transfer /code

# Change to non-root user and change to our imported code directory
USER transfer
WORKDIR /code

# Run tests
CMD lein test-out junit
{noformat}

On 'docker run' the WORKDIR will be overridden, causing 'lein test-out' to fail.
fields.summary: Docker run task overrides the WORKDIR directive in Dockerfile

fields.description:
As described on the KB below:
- [Remote agent points to localhost and not to Bamboo's server IP|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Remote+agent+points+to+localhost+and+not+to+Bamboo%27s+server+IP]

We should stop customers from configuring {{localhost}} for the Broker URL during the [Setup Wizard|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Running+the+Setup+Wizard#RunningtheSetupWizard-Step2.GeneralConfiguration]

This shouldn't be allowed or at least strongly suggested to be changed *during the Set up Wizard* as in the future connecting remote agents will fail.
fields.summary: Stop users from using localhost on the Broker URL during set up

fields.description:
Please refer to [Remote agent points to localhost and not to Bamboo's server IP|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Remote+agent+points+to+localhost+and+not+to+Bamboo%27s+server+IP] for more details.

Basically, when starting the agent it'd be helpful if this message was a FATAL error on the remote agent instead of INFO:
{noformat:atlassian-bamboo.log}
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2015/05/17 19:35:47 | 2015-05-17 19:35:46,991 WARN [Thread-0] [BambooActiveMQConnectionFactory] Broker URI: tcp://localhost:54663?wireFormat.maxInactivityDuration=300000 is invalid: java.net.
ConnectException: Connection refused
{noformat}

If the remote agent hits that, it will continue loading on the Bamboo UI and it won't be fixed until the solution described on the KB is applied.
fields.summary: Change Broker URI Connection refused message from INFO to FATAL

fields.description:
I'm running a script job (a shell script), which in turns runs some python scripts, on an elastic bamboo agent (AWS/EC2). The python script occasionally sends messages to our internal messaging system.
I stop the build (via the 'Actions' menu), and bamboo shows the job as 'Stopped' and gray. However, I still get messages coming in from the python script. When I log into the elastic instance, I can see the python process is still active, parented to the root process.

The Stop Job action should kill the entire process tree.

version: 5.9-OD-02-054
buildDate: 2015-05-06T09:30:45.000+03:00
buildNumber: 5909
fields.summary: Stopped a build job, but process continues to run (on an elastic agent)

fields.summary: Cannot view agents that can run a build when all of those agents are offline

fields.description: Attempting this report having selected all users in an instance generates a 400 Error with the text "Request Header Or Cookie Too Large".  Adding one at a time, it is successful up until about 50 users selected, where it begins to fail.
fields.summary: User and author statistics Build Activity report fails with large numbers of users

fields.description:
Hello,

Please add an admin configuration to connect to HipChat server without having to deal with etc/hosts as I found on the web as to what is required to post to my team room.

Thank you.
fields.summary: Add HipChat server configuration in Bamboo Admin
